newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: FOCUS-Akzo has flat third quarter profits.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Akzo has flat third quarter profits.

text.p: Dutch chemicals group Akzo Nobel NV on Wednesday announced fractionally higher third quarter net profits but said it was targeting increased profitability through continued expansion of its most profitable activities.
Net profit came in at 328 million guilders ($193.4 million) versus 324 million guilders a year earlier, with operating profits at 510 million guilders versus 494 million guilders.
"This is the first quarter of this year in which not only sales but also operating income and net earnings improved," outgoing finance director Syb Bergsma told a news conference.

"We therefore maintain our earlier view that for the full year net income excluding extraordinary items will be of the same order of magnitude as in 1995," he said, adding the group did not expect to post any one-off gains or losses in 1996.
Bergsma said a 40 percent jump in operating earnings at the group's coatings division had been almost wiped out by lower contributions from fibres and chemicals.

Akzo would continue to shift the emphasis of its activities towards high-margin pharmaceuticals and coatings in the future, in a drive to achieve its profitability target of a 20 percent return on investment, Bergsma said.
"It is clearly our strategy to become more of a pharma and coatings company," he said, adding "that's where the growth has to come from, these are the areas of higher margins."
Coatings and pharmaceuticals generated some two-thirds of group operating profit in the first nine months of this year and a hefty 80 percent in the third quarter, Bergsma said.
He said return on investment for the group as a whole currently amounted to around 16 percent.
Bergsma said that in coatings, the synergy effects of the 1994 merger between Akzo and Sweden's Nobel were paying off.
Chemicals had been hit by lower bulk selling prices although specialty chemicals had turned in improved results, he said.
Pharmaceutical earnings were braked by the aftermath of the contraceptive pill scare which broke in October last year, hurting sales in Britain and Germany, Bergsma said.
"The pill debate wasn't reflected in last year's third-quarter figure," he said, but added the sales appeared to have bottomed out and were starting to pick up again.
Start-up costs for two new drugs with high earnings potential had also depressed pharmaceuticals profits, Bergsma said.

Remeron, an anti-depressant Akzo claims has performed better in trials than well-known rival Prozac, is expected to unlock a billion-guilder market, while fertility drug Puregon is seen generating hundreds of millions of guilders in sales in time.
The figures gained a lukewarm reception from analysts, who had forecast third quarter net of 298-364 million guilders, with the consensus at 336 million.
Most believed chemicals could have turned in a better performance.
"The results were slightly below our estimates," said Andreas de Groot, analyst with MeesPierson. "What disappointed was the chemicals activities...but coatings was far more positive."

"I would have thought the chemicals division could have done better," agreed Quirijn Mulder of ING Barings Research. "I am still rating the company as an outperformer, but bringing my earnings per share forecasts for 1996 down a little."
On the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, Akzo shares shed three guilders to 214.60 by 1230 GMT. ($1=1.696 Guilder)
